intro: Vincetoxicum crassipes, commonly known as the broad-leaved snakeroot, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves and showy, yellowish-orange flowers. The plant contains toxic compounds, including alkaloids, which have historically been used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Vincetoxicum crassipes is also known for its ability to spread through rhizomes, making it a persistent weed in certain regions.
